title: Vendor Requirements Guide
description: Select the type of vendor you are sourcing to see the required tier and what you should request before onboarding.

q_vendor_type.text:
What type of vendor are you sourcing?
Choose the option that best matches the vendor's role.

No data and no system access (e.g. stati.explanation:
Tier: ðŸŸ¢ Tier 3 â€“ Low Risk

The vendor does not access systems and does not process your data.

What to request:
- Basic contract
- Pricing details
- Delivery or service terms

Not required:
- No DPA
- No SLA
- No security questionnaires
- No SOC 2/ISO evidence

Examples:
- Stationery supplier
- Catering services
- Cleaning company
- Uniform suppliers
- Furniture providers

Why this matters:
Because the vendor has no access to systems or data, they pose almost no security or privacy risk. Keeping requirements light avoids unnecessary paperwork and speeds up procurement.

Low/internal data only (e.g. training to.explanation:
Tier: ðŸŸ¡ Tier 2 â€“ Medium Risk

The vendor handles low-sensitivity or internal-only data.

What to request:
- Light SLA (response times)
- High-level security policy
- Data storage region
- Data retention period
- DPA only if personal data is involved

Not required:
- No SOC 2/ISO mandatory
- No heavy questionnaires
- No DR/BCM evidence

Examples:
- Staff learning platforms
- Internal survey tools
- Department-only scheduling tools
- Basic SaaS utilities used internally

Why this matters:
These services touch internal or operational data but do not carry high privacy or security risk. The focus is ensuring they handle data responsibly without overwhelming the vendor with enterprise-level requirements.

Personal data or integration (e.g. HR, C.explanation:
Tier: ðŸŸ  Tier 1 â€“ High Risk

The vendor processes personal data and/or integrates with your systems.

What to request:
- DPA
- Sub-processor list
- SLA (uptime + support)
- ISO 27001, SOC 2, or pen test
- MFA and access control summary
- Data flow diagram
- 48-hour incident notification
- Exit and deletion plan

Examples:
- HR systems
- CRM platforms
- Payroll/timekeeping tools
- SaaS with user accounts
- API providers sending or receiving your data

Why this matters:
Personal data and system integrations increase both privacy risk and cyber exposure. These requirements ensure the vendor follows strong security practices and that you can track how data flows through their service.

Critical/high-impact service (e.g. cloud.explanation:
Tier: ðŸ”´ Tier 0 â€“ Critical

The vendor supports critical services or has privileged access.

What to request:
- DPA (if personal data)
- Strong contract with security clauses
- SOC 2 Type II and/or ISO 27001
- Pen test summary
- Security architecture overview
- MFA and privileged access controls
- SLA with uptime guarantee
- BCM/DR documentation + test evidence
- 24-hour incident notification
- Detailed exit plan and data deletion confirmation

Examples:
- AWS, Azure, GCP
- Enterprise-wide identity provider (Okta, Entra)
- Core clinical or business systems
- Payment processors
- Managed service providers with admin access

Why this matters:
Critical vendors create direct operational dependency. A failure, breach, or outage would significantly disrupt your organisation. These requirements ensure you have deep assurance, resilience, and strong contractual protections.
